original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1938-1948, applied mathematics saw significant advancements in communication theory through Claude Shannon's foundational work on information transmission. Earlier developments like the estimation of fifty percent endpoints (1938) and elasticity theories provided mathematical tools for analyzing complex systems, leading to a focus on quantitative methods for solving practical problems.

representative_papers.title: A Mathematical Theory of Communication
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the advancements in communication theory, particularly focusing on modulation methods like PCM and PPM that optimize bandwidth and signal-to-noise ratio. It aims to extend existing theories by incorporating new factors such as noise effects and the statistical structure of messages, drawing on foundational works by Nyquist and Hartley.

Topic: graph theory, applied mathematics, spectral theory, information theory, communication theory, mathematical control theory, mathematical optimization, mass communication, wavelet theory, mathematical theory, theoretical mathematics, scientific communication, communication complexity, mathematics, theory of computation, communication, speech communication, mathematical programming

representative_papers.title: A SIMPLE METHOD OF ESTIMATING FIFTY PER CENT ENDPOINTS12
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a straightforward method for estimating fifty percent endpoints, utilizing geometric interpolation and curve fitting techniques, which can be applied in various fields such as epidemiology, economics, and machine learning research for performance evaluation and comparative analysis.

Topic: economics, quantitative science study, partial evaluation, curve fitting, applied mathematics, simple method, geometric interpolation, benchmark study, statistics, machine learning research, performance evaluation, comparative analysis, numerical simulation

representative_papers.title: Theory of elasticity
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of the theory of elasticity, covering fundamental concepts such as stresses and strains, plasticity, and elasto-plastic behavior in materials. It explores various mechanical phenomena and applications in structural mechanics, emphasizing nonlinear elasticity and the mathematical principles underlying mechanical deformation.

Topic: mechanical behavior, mechanical engineering, metal, nonlinear elasticity, friction, nonlinear analysis, deformation, structural mechanics, elasticity (physics), rational mechanic, mechanical property, nonlinear phenomenon, applied mathematics, mechanical deformation, elasticity (economics), solid mechanics, mechanics of materials, physics

representative_papers.title: A Method of Computing the Effectiveness of an Insecticide
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a method for calculating the effectiveness of insecticides, focusing on the application of mathematical and statistical techniques in pest management and entomology. It aims to enhance the understanding of insecticide performance through a systematic approach to data analysis.

Topic: insecticide, pesticide science, applied mathematics, pest management, insect science, biostatistics, entomology

representative_papers.title: The Mathematical Theory of Communication
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the enduring significance of "The Mathematical Theory of Communication," a groundbreaking work in communication theory published over fifty years ago, which has influenced various fields such as information theory, mathematics, and communication. It highlights the book's remarkable foresight and its continued relevance, as evidenced by multiple printings and a recent commemorative reissue by the University of Illinois Press.

Topic: information theory, theory of computation, spectral theory, wavelet theory, mathematics, general system, graph theory, communication, mathematical theory, mathematical optimization, mathematical logic, communication theory, theoretical mathematics, applied mathematics, mathematical programming, communication complexity, mathematical control theory, speech communication, mass communication

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Stochastic Processes and Graph Theory in Applied Mathematics
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period of 1949-1958, applied mathematics experienced significant advancements through the development and application of stochastic processes to model complex phenomena like diffusion (The mathematics of diffusion, 1956) and irreversible processes. Concurrently, graph theory emerged as a crucial tool for solving combinatorial optimization problems, with papers such as On the shortest spanning subtree... providing foundational algorithms. These two paradigms developed somewhat independently but both reflected a broader shift towards probabilistic and discrete methods in tackling practical challenges.

representative_papers.title: On the shortest spanning subtree of a graph and the traveling salesman problem
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the relationship between the shortest spanning subtree of a graph and the traveling salesman problem, highlighting key concepts in graph theory, combinatorial optimization, and algebraic graph theory. It references significant works and problems in the field, emphasizing their implications for graph algorithms and mathematical structures.

Topic: graph theory, applied mathematics, algebraic graph theory, combinatorial optimization, graph algorithm

representative_papers.title: The mathematics of diffusion
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the mathematics of diffusion, focusing on the collection of solutions to diffusion equations and the methods for obtaining them, while also addressing various related topics such as nonlinear phenomena, boundary value problems, and numerical simulations in the context of diffusion processes.

Topic: applied mathematics, nonlinear phenomenon, boundary value problem, partial differential equation, differential equation, nonlinear dynamic, diffusion, anomalous diffusion, diffusion process, numerical simulation, information diffusion, stochastic diffusion search, mathematics, numerical mathematics, diffusion of innovation, stochastic process, transport phenomena

representative_papers.title: Boundary layer theory
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses boundary layer theory, focusing on the differences in flow behavior at high Reynolds numbers compared to laminar flow, particularly highlighting the characteristics of turbulence in pipe flow. It emphasizes the need for nonlinear analysis and advanced mathematical methods to understand the complexities of fluid motion near surfaces in various scientific and engineering applications.

Topic: nonlinear analysis, boundary element method, boundary value problem, civil engineering, materials science, boundary layer, applied mathematics, interface (matter), interface science, layered material, tectonics, partial differential equation, shell theory, boundary layer theory, surface science, solid mechanics

representative_papers.title: Methods of Theoretical Physics
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses various methods and approaches in theoretical physics, focusing on high-energy physics, applied mathematics, and computational techniques. It explores the intersection of theoretical modeling and mathematical physics, highlighting their significance in addressing theoretical issues within the field.

Topic: theoretical high-energy physic, applied mathematics, particle method, computational physic, mathematical physics, theoretical issue, theoretical mathematics, physics, theoretical modeling, theoretical physic, applied physics

representative_papers.title: Statistical-Mechanical Theory of Irreversible Processes. I. General Theory and Simple Applications to Magnetic and Conduction Problems
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a comprehensive exploration of a general fluctuation-dissipation theorem within the framework of statistical-mechanical theory, detailing how physical quantities like magnetic susceptibility and conductivity can be derived from time-fluctuation dynamics related to irreversible processes. It includes a rigorous examination of the formalism, response and correlation functions, and illustrates these concepts through simple applications in magnetic and conduction problems.

Topic: magnetism, thermal engineering, path dependence, irreversible processes, stochastic calculus, mechanical engineering, statistical-mechanical theory, simple applications, statistical theory, stochastic process, statistical inference, statistics, statistical mechanic, mathematical statistic, theoretical analysis, applied mathematics, magnetic resonance, conduction problems, statistical signal processing, nonlinear dynamic, statistical model, general theory, reliability engineering

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1959-1964, applied mathematics witnessed a surge in the study of nonlinear phenomena through rigorous mathematical analysis (An Analysis of Transformations, 1964) as well as innovative numerical methods for function minimization (Function minimization by conjugate gradients, 1964; An efficient method for finding the minimum...). The domain also saw advancements in computational approaches to complex systems like electrochemistry and polarography (Theory of Stationary Electrode Polarography..., 1964), reflecting a growing integration between mathematical theory and algorithmic computation. These developments built upon earlier stochastic modeling paradigms while establishing new foundations for tackling problems that required handling nonlinearity, which was central in many scientific applications from physics to engineering.

representative_papers.title: An Analysis of Transformations
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a less restrictive approach to data analysis by allowing for transformations of observations to achieve normality and homoscedasticity, rather than assuming these conditions from the outset. It explores the implications of these transformations on likelihood functions and posterior distributions, while also comparing current methods to earlier procedures for finding suitable transformations, supported by illustrative examples.

Topic: organizational transformation, cultural change, transformation kinetics, nonlinear analysis, nonlinear phenomenon, applied mathematics, energy transformation, chemical transformation, social transformation, integral transform

representative_papers.title: Principles of mathematical analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of the principles of mathematical analysis, covering topics such as number systems, topology, sequences, continuity, differentiation, integration, and advanced concepts like Lebesgue theory and differential forms, while also touching on various branches of mathematics including complex analysis and functional analysis. It serves as a foundational resource for understanding both theoretical and applied aspects of mathematical analysis.

Topic: mathematics, analytic number theory, nonlinear analysis, numerical mathematics, matrix analysis, abstract and applied analysis, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, complex analysis, foundation of mathematics, spectral theory, numerical analysis, mathematical science, functional analysis, abstract analysis, global analysis, mathematical analysis

representative_papers.title: Theory of Stationary Electrode Polarography. Single Scan and Cyclic Methods Applied to Reversible, Irreversible, and Kinetic Systems.
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the theory and application of stationary electrode polarography, focusing on single scan and cyclic methods for analyzing reversible, irreversible, and kinetic systems in electroanalytical chemistry. It provides insights into the underlying principles and methodologies relevant to electrical engineering and biophysics.

Topic: relaxation process, cyclic methods, electrical engineering, polarization imaging, kinetic systems, applied mathematics, stationary electrode polarography, electroanalytical chemistry, biophysics, electrochemistry

representative_papers.title: Function minimization by conjugate gradients
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a quadratically convergent gradient method for finding unconstrained local minima of multivariable functions, highlighting its simplicity and low storage requirements, as it only needs three vectors. It includes an ALGOL procedure and discusses results from various test functions to demonstrate the method's effectiveness in mathematical optimization.

Topic: computer science, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, function minimization, conjugate gradients, functional analysis

representative_papers.title: An efficient method for finding the minimum of a function of several variables without calculating derivatives
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents an efficient derivative-free method for minimizing functions of several variables by adjusting one parameter at a time, which enhances convergence rates and ensures effective approximations of the minimum. Practical applications and numerical examples demonstrate the method's effectiveness in optimizing functions with up to twenty variables.

Topic: several variables, computer science, approximation theory, variational analysis, global optimization, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, mathematical programming, derivative-free optimization, optimization problem, systems engineering, numerical analysis, multivariate approximation, efficient method, combinatorial optimization, conic optimization, design optimization, computational optimization

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1965-1978, applied mathematics was characterized by an intensive focus on numerical methods for analyzing complex nonlinear systems. This period saw the development of robust algorithms for optimization (e.g., 'A Simplex Method for Function Minimization') and computational approaches to fluid dynamics ('Numerical Calculation of Time-Dependent Viscous Incompressible Flow of Fluid with Free Surface'). The research emphasized stability, accuracy, and efficient computation in handling differential equations that govern phenomena from quantum mechanics to fluid behavior. This built upon earlier advancements in stochastic modeling and numerical optimization while addressing the increasing demand for computational solutions to intricate scientific problems.

representative_papers.title: Self-Consistent Equations Including Exchange and Correlation Effects
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of approximation methods for treating inhomogeneous systems of interacting electrons, building on the Hohenberg and Kohn theory. It presents self-consistent equations that incorporate exchange and correlation effects, analogous to Hartree and Hartree-Fock equations, and addresses the behavior of electronic systems at finite temperatures and in magnetic fields, along with corrections for short-wavelength density oscillations.

Topic: stability, differential equation, quantum science, dynamic equilibrium, correlation effects, diffusion, dynamical system, nonlinear phenomenon, applied mathematics, correlation, coexistence, coherent process, simultaneous equation modeling, applied physics, self-consistent equations, numerical simulation, ecology, bifurcation theory

representative_papers.title: A Simplex Method for Function Minimization
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a simplex method for minimizing functions of multiple variables by utilizing a general simplex structure that adapts to the local landscape, effectively replacing the vertex with the highest value to converge on the minimum. It highlights the computational efficiency of the approach and provides a procedure for estimating the Hessian matrix in the vicinity of the minimum, relevant for statistical applications.

Topic: computer science, function minimization, mathematical optimization, simplex method, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: A Theory of the Allocation of Time
representative_papers.abstract:
The article "A Theory of the Allocation of Time" by Gary S. Becker explores the economic principles governing how individuals allocate their time among various activities, integrating concepts from dynamic economics, mathematical optimization, and systems theory to analyze the complexities of time management as a resource.

Topic: economics, complex system, dynamic economics, temporal dynamic, theoretical economics, systems biology, dynamical system, applied mathematics, mathematical optimization, automatic control, ergodic theory, time series, temporal complexity, resource allocation, time delay system

representative_papers.title: Numerical Calculation of Time-Dependent Viscous Incompressible Flow of Fluid with Free Surface
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel numerical technique for analyzing time-dependent, viscous, incompressible fluid flow with a free surface, utilizing finite-difference methods to solve the Navier-Stokes equations. It incorporates a cell method with marker particles to track fluid movement, allowing for comprehensive simulation of non-linear and transient flow behaviors.

Topic: free surface, incompressible flow, unsteady flow, fluid flow, flow physic, applied mathematics, numerical calculation, numerical analysis, fluid dynamics, numerical simulation, fluid mechanics, computational fluid dynamic

representative_papers.title: The Fourier Transform and Its Applications
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of the Fourier Transform, covering its foundational concepts, mathematical principles, and various applications across fields such as statistics, optics, and heat conduction. It includes discussions on convolution, discrete Fourier transforms, and related theories, making it a valuable resource for understanding the significance and utility of Fourier analysis in applied mathematics and engineering.

Topic: applied mathematics, operator theory, spectral theory, fourier transform, harmonic analysis, fourier expansion, fourier analysis

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1979-1986, applied mathematics was dominated by advancements in statistics. This period saw the development of robust methods for handling heteroskedasticity (A Heteroskedasticity-Consistent Covariance Matrix Estimator...) and high-dimensional data through multivariate analysis (An Introduction to Multivariate Statistical Analysis). The integration of statistical theory with computational techniques, such

representative_papers.title: An Introduction to Multivariate Statistical Analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
This article serves as a comprehensive introduction to multivariate statistical analysis, covering key topics such as the multivariate normal distribution, estimation of mean vectors and covariance matrices, classification of observations, and various statistical tests and methodologies, including principal components and factor analysis. It is designed for readers interested in applied statistics and statistical theory, particularly in the context of high-dimensional data and biostatistics.

Topic: applied statistics, applied mathematics, statistical theory, multivariate analysis, biostatistics, high-dimensional statistics, statistics, statistical methodology

representative_papers.title: Norm-Conserving Pseudopotentials
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a straightforward method for deriving norm-conserving pseudopotentials from ab initio atomic calculations, ensuring that the resulting eigenvalues and nodeless eigenfunctions align with wave functions beyond a specified radius, thus enhancing the pseudopotentials' transferability.

Topic: mathematics, norm-conserving pseudopotentials, linear algebra, quantum science, parameter identification, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, norm (mathematics), spectral theory, condensed matter physics, functional analysis, regularization (mathematics)

representative_papers.title: Spectrum estimation and harmonic analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
This article presents a novel method for spectrum estimation of stationary time series using local eigenexpansion, addressing bias control and smoothing issues without arbitrary windows. The approach is computationally efficient, consistent, and offers high resolution, while also providing analysis-of-variance tests and connections to maximum-likelihood estimates and polyspectrum coherence.

Topic: spectrum estimation, applied mathematics, harmonic analysis

representative_papers.title: Official Methods of Analysis of
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the Official Methods of Analysis, focusing on the methodologies and statistical techniques used in various fields, including political science and economic analysis, to evaluate performance and conduct quantitative research. It highlights the importance of formal methods and statistical methodologies in ensuring accurate and reliable results in applied statistics.

Topic: methodology comparison, political science research, evaluation technique, methodological article, statistical theory, economic analysis, applied statistics, performance studies, methodological development, statistics, performance evaluation, quantitative science study, mathematical analysis, official methods, formal methods, statistical methodology, statistical analysis, applied mathematics, software analysis

representative_papers.title: A Heteroskedasticity-Consistent Covariance Matrix Estimator and a Direct Test for Heteroskedasticity
representative_papers.abstract:
This article introduces a heteroskedasticity-consistent covariance matrix estimator for linear regression models that remains valid regardless of the specific structure of heteroskedasticity. It also provides a direct test for heteroskedasticity by comparing this new estimator with traditional ones, highlighting their divergence in the presence of heteroskedastic disturbances.

Topic: high-dimensional statistics, econometric method, applied mathematics, direct test, statistics

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period of 1987-1994, applied mathematics was characterized by significant advancements in statistical inference methods. The publication of 'An Introduction to the Bootstrap' (1994) exemplifies this trend with its focus on resampling techniques for robust estimation and confidence intervals. Concurrently, papers such as 'Applied Logistic Regression' (1990) demonstrate a growing interest in applied statistics for analyzing categorical data and health-related phenomena. The period also saw continued developments in numerical analysis, particularly through the study of nonlinear systems using quaternions ('Closed-form solution of absolute orientation using unit quaternions', 1987). These two themes coexisted and evolved somewhat independently but reflected a broader integration of mathematical theory with practical data analysis problems.

representative_papers.title: Real and Complex Analysis.
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of real and complex analysis, covering key topics such as abstract integration, Lp-spaces, Hilbert space theory, and holomorphic functions, along with their applications in various mathematical contexts. It includes detailed discussions on measures, differentiation, transforms, and properties of analytic functions, making it a valuable resource for both theoretical and applied mathematics.

Topic: nonlinear analysis, abstract and applied analysis, applied mathematics, complex analysis, real analysis, real algebraic geometry, mathematical analysis

representative_papers.title: Closed-form solution of absolute orientation using unit quaternions
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a closed-form solution for determining the absolute orientation between two coordinate systems using unit quaternions, addressing a classic problem in photogrammetry and robotics. It simplifies the least-squares approach for aligning three or more points by emphasizing the symmetry properties of the rotation and providing exact results that outperform traditional empirical and iterative methods.

Topic: geometry and topology, computer science, geometric modeling, spectral theory, planetary sciences, geometry processing, algebraic geometry, unit quaternions, structure from motion, geometric quantization, absolute orientation, clifford algebra, computational geometry, differential geometry, function space, machine vision, geometric topology, closed-form solution, integral geometry, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: An Introduction to the Bootstrap
representative_papers.abstract:
This article introduces bootstrap methods for statistical estimation, providing straightforward explanations and Minitab macros for implementation. It covers key concepts in statistical inference and machine learning, emphasizing the practical applications of bootstrap resampling in data science.

Topic: computer science, forecasting, bootstrap resampling, statistical foundation, theory of computation, statistical inference, machine learning, applied mathematics, numerical algorithm, empirical algorithmics, foundation of mathematics, data science, knowledge discovery, statistical theory, machine learning research, quantitative science study, foundation model

representative_papers.title: Applied logistic regression
representative_papers.abstract:
The article reviews the revised edition of "Applied Logistic Regression" by David Stanley, highlighting its accessible approach to logistic regression models, minimal use of mathematics, and incorporation of recent advancements in biostatistics and machine learning. It emphasizes the book's practical examples and comprehensive guidance for readers across various fields, making it a valuable resource for statisticians and data scientists.

Topic: applied statistics, applied mathematics, applied economics, statistics, statistical inference, applied logic, model selection, logistic regression, classification method, data science, applied probability

representative_papers.title: Structural equation modeling in practice: A review and recommended two-step approach.
representative_papers.abstract:
This article offers a practical guide for researchers on implementing structural equation modeling (SEM) in theory testing and development, presenting a recommended two-step approach that utilizes nested models and chi-square difference tests. It highlights the advantages of this method over a one-step approach and reviews key considerations in model specification, fit assessment, and measurement respecification through confirmatory factor analysis.

Topic: applied mathematics, modeling and simulation, structural equation modeling, mathematical model

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1995-1998, applied mathematics was dominated by advancements in numerical methods for solving partial differential equations (PDEs), particularly through the development of efficient iterative schemes and computational techniques. The papers 'A smooth particle mesh Ewald method' from 1995 introduced a novel approach to PDE-based simulations using particle-based discretizations combined with FFT acceleration, while 'Computational Electrodynamics: The Finite-Difference Time-Domain Method' also from 1995 provided a systematic framework for time-dependent electromagnetic problems. Concurrently, the focus on generalized gradient approximations in density functional theory (e.g., 'Generalized Gradient Approximation Made Simple') highlights an ongoing interest in improving numerical methods within quantum mechanics and condensed matter physics, demonstrating how these paradigms built upon earlier developments from periods 1-6 by refining computation for increasingly complex physical systems.

representative_papers.title: Generalized Gradient Approximation Made Simple
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a simplified derivation of generalized gradient approximations (GGA) for exchange-correlation energy, enhancing the local spin density (LSD) approach by using fundamental constants and building on the Perdew-Wang 1991 (PW91) framework, while offering improvements in linear response, scaling behavior, and potential smoothness.

Topic: mathematics, computer science, approximation theory, approximation method, gradient approximation, mathematical optimization, low-rank approximation, applied mathematics, numerical analysis, machine learning research, computational optimization

representative_papers.title: Efficient iterative schemes forab initiototal-energy calculations using a plane-wave basis set
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents an efficient iterative scheme for calculating the Kohn-Sham ground state of metallic systems using pseudopotentials and a plane-wave basis set, focusing on the application of Pulay's DIIS method for matrix diagonalization and a novel preconditioning technique. It demonstrates that the proposed algorithms, implemented in the VASP package, achieve reliable results with reduced computational scaling, making them effective for various materials, including liquid semiconductors and transition metals.

Topic: approximation theory, energy minimization, algorithmic development, applied mathematics, plane-wave basis set, efficient iterative schemes, ab-initio method

representative_papers.title: A smooth particle mesh Ewald method
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a reformulation of the particle mesh Ewald method using efficient B-spline interpolation for structure factors, enabling the extension to potentials of the form 1/r^p with p≥1. This approach enhances accuracy and allows for arbitrary precision in calculations, making it particularly suitable for biomolecular systems with thousands of atoms while maintaining computational efficiency.

Topic: finite element method, particle method, numerical method for partial differential equation, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, numerical algorithm, unstructured mesh generation, numerical analysis, mesh optimization, numerical simulation, computational optimization
keywords: numerical method for partial differential equation

representative_papers.title: Computational Electrodynamics: The Finite-Difference Time-Domain Method
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of the Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) method in computational electrodynamics, detailing its historical development, numerical techniques, and applications in modeling electromagnetic fields, particularly in defense and high-speed electronic circuits. It covers key concepts such as stability, dispersion, absorbing boundary conditions, and advanced modeling techniques for complex geometries and materials.

Topic: computational electrodynamics, numerical computation, electrical engineering, numerical mathematics, numerical method for partial differential equation, applied mathematics, numerical algorithm, computational mechanics, numerical analysis, computational electromagnetics, applied physics, partial differential equation, finite-difference time-domain method, numerical simulation, scientific computing, computational science
keywords: numerical method for partial differential equation

representative_papers.title: Finite Element Procedures
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of finite element procedures, covering fundamental concepts in engineering analysis, formulation methods for solid mechanics, and applications in nonlinear problems, heat transfer, and fluid flows, along with discussions on dynamic analysis and eigenproblems. It serves as a resource for understanding the mathematical and numerical foundations of the finite element method in engineering contexts.

Topic: finite element method, engineering, finite element procedures, applied mathematics, numerical analysis

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Nonlinear Dimensionality Reduction and Systems Modeling
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period of 1999-2002, applied mathematics was characterized by significant advancements in nonlinear dimensionality reduction techniques (e.g., 'Nonlinear Dimensionality Reduction by Locally Linear Embedding') and systems modeling approaches. These developments built upon earlier numerical methods for complex systems from periods 3-6, providing new tools for analyzing high-dimensional data and structural relationships within scientific applications.

representative_papers.title: Nonlinear Dimensionality Reduction by Locally Linear Embedding
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Locally Linear Embedding (LLE), an unsupervised learning algorithm designed for nonlinear dimensionality reduction, which creates low-dimensional representations of high-dimensional data while preserving local neighborhood structures. LLE distinguishes itself by mapping inputs into a global coordinate system without relying on clustering methods, making it effective for analyzing complex data structures like images and text documents.

Topic: computer science, dimensionality reduction, nonlinear analysis, machine learning, applied mathematics, machine learning research, nonlinear dimensionality reduction

representative_papers.title: Structural equation modeling with AMOS: basic concepts, applications, and programming
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of structural equation modeling (SEM) using AMOS, covering fundamental concepts, practical applications, and programming techniques. It includes detailed discussions on single-group and multiple-group analyses, factorial validity, latent mean differences, and advanced topics such as growth curves and multilevel variance.

Topic: computer science, structural equation, systems modeling, applied mathematics, mathematical programming, basic concepts, modeling and simulation, applied mathematical modelling

representative_papers.title: A climbing image nudged elastic band method for finding saddle points and minimum energy paths
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a modified nudged elastic band method for identifying saddle points and minimum energy paths, utilizing climbing images and variable spring constants to enhance accuracy near energy barriers. Applications of this method are demonstrated in the context of CH4 dissociative adsorption on Ir(111) and H2 on Si(100) using plane wave-based functional theory.

Topic: image analysis, mechanical engineering, rock engineering, control optimization, trajectory optimization, saddle points, elastic band method, kinesiology, numerical simulation, machine vision, digital image processing, energy minimization, optimal transport, curve fitting, deformation, curve modeling, applied mathematics, climbing image, minimum energy paths

representative_papers.title: An Introduction to Fluid Dynamics
representative_papers.abstract:
"An Introduction to Fluid Dynamics" by Professor Batchelor, first published in 1967, remains a seminal text in the field, offering a comprehensive and elegant presentation of fluid dynamics theories that are still relevant today. This re-issue aims to introduce a new generation of graduate students to the foundational concepts of fluid mechanics, including topics such as hydrodynamic stability, numerical simulation, and biofluid dynamics.

Topic: applied mathematics, friction, flow physic, hydrodynamic stability, fluid-solid interaction, mechanical engineering, complex fluid, numerical simulation, hydraulics, fluid science, computational fluid dynamic, fluid mechanics, multiphase flow, fluid flow, biofluid dynamic, fluid dynamics, transport phenomena, applied physics

representative_papers.title: Finite Mixture Models
representative_papers.abstract:
The article highlights the significance of finite mixture models in statistical analysis, emphasizing their growing application across various fields, including applied mathematics and machine learning research. It discusses the theoretical foundations and practical implications of these models in mixture analysis and numerical simulations.

Topic: applied mathematics, computational model, numerical simulation, mixture analysis, finite model theory, finite mixture models, machine learning research, mixture distribution, statistical model

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Advancements in Optimization Algorithms for Machine Learning
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period of 2003-2006, applied mathematics saw significant progress through the development of optimization algorithms tailored to machine learning applications. Papers like K-SVD (2006) introduced novel methods for designing overcomplete dictionaries essential for sparse representation tasks in areas such as signal processing and image analysis. Concurrently, tools like YALMIP (2005), an optimization toolbox for MATLAB, provided researchers with accessible platforms to model complex problems efficiently across various domains including systems engineering and intelligent systems. These advancements built upon earlier numerical methods from period 4 while integrating more directly with data-driven paradigms emerging in statistics research during periods 5-8.

representative_papers.title: Flocking for Multi-Agent Dynamic Systems: Algorithms and Theory
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a theoretical framework for designing and analyzing distributed flocking algorithms in multi-agent dynamic systems, addressing scenarios in free space with obstacles. It introduces three algorithms—two for free flocking and one for constrained flocking—while exploring the emergence of collective behavior and demonstrating various simulation results for complex maneuvers in both 2-D and 3-D environments.

Topic: distributed system, computer science, intelligent systems, multi-agent dynamic systems, robotics, multi-agent learning, complex system, control optimization, multiagent system, swarm intelligence, dynamical system, multi-agent planning, cybernetics, systems engineering, automatic control, autonomous agent system, multi-agent mechanism design, applied mathematics, collective motion

representative_papers.title: Applied Regression Analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of applied regression analysis, covering essential topics such as least squares fitting, multiple regression, model selection, and advanced techniques like ridge regression and generalized linear models. It also includes practical elements like exercises, bibliographic references, and statistical methodologies relevant to econometrics and applied statistics.

Topic: statistical methodology, econometrics, applied statistics, statistical analysis, statistical inference, applied mathematics, applied probability, biostatistics, applied economics, applied mathematical modelling, statistics, regression analysis, economic analysis, regression testing

representative_papers.title: Principal Component Analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses Principal Component Analysis (PCA), a technique used to reduce the dimensionality of large multivariate datasets by transforming original variables into a smaller set of derived variables, or principal components, while retaining most of the data's variability. It also addresses various subtleties, choices, and extensions related to PCA, including normalization methods and its applications in fields such as statistics, machine learning, and exploratory data analysis.

Topic: applied mathematics, systems engineering, multidimensional analysis, network analysis, high-dimensional statistics, exploratory data analysis, statistics, independent component analysis, principal component analysis, quantitative science study, machine learning research, content analysis, numerical linear algebra, representation analysis, image analysis

representative_papers.title: $rm K$-SVD: An Algorithm for Designing Overcomplete Dictionaries for Sparse Representation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents the $rm K$-SVD algorithm, a novel method for designing overcomplete dictionaries aimed at improving sparse representation of signals. It details how the algorithm iteratively updates dictionary atoms to enhance signal representation under strict sparsity constraints, demonstrating its effectiveness through synthetic tests and real image data applications.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, dimensionality reduction, compressive sensing, natural language processing, hierarchical classification, clustering, applied mathematics, data science, sparse representation, image representation, machine learning research, feature construction, overcomplete dictionaries, computational science

representative_papers.title: YALMIP : a toolbox for modeling and optimization in MATLAB
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces YALMIP, a MATLAB toolbox designed for modeling and solving optimization problems in systems control theory, highlighting its user-friendly interface and simplicity, which allows users to effectively tackle semidefinite programming (SDP) tasks with minimal commands.

Topic: mathematical modelling, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, model optimization, modeling and simulation, computational optimization

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: **Representative Papers** such as 'Adam' (2014) highlight advancements in stochastic optimization algorithms, particularly for training deep neural networks. Concurrently, papers like 'Exact Matrix Completion via Convex Optimization' (2009) demonstrate the use of convex methods to solve complex problems in high-dimensional statistics and machine learning. Additionally, 'Robust principal component analysis?' (2011) exemplifies robust optimization techniques that handle outliers effectively. These themes coexist because stochastic approaches provide scalability for large datasets while convex formulations ensure tractability with guarantees on optimality or convergence; together they enable powerful data-driven methods in areas such as image processing and feature extraction.

representative_papers.title: Exact Matrix Completion via Convex Optimization
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a method for recovering low-rank matrices from a limited number of randomly sampled entries using convex optimization techniques. It establishes that if the number of sampled entries meets a specific threshold, the original matrix can be perfectly reconstructed by minimizing its nuclear norm, with implications for various applications in compressed sensing and data reconstruction.

Topic: computer science, dimensionality reduction, exact matrix completion, numerical linear algebra, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: Robust principal component analysis?
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a method for robust principal component analysis that enables the separation of low-rank and sparse components from a data matrix, even when a significant portion of the data is corrupted. It introduces Principal Component Pursuit, a convex optimization approach that minimizes a combination of nuclear and ℓ1 norms, and explores its applications in fields such as video surveillance and image analysis.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, high-dimensional statistics, robust feature, machine learning, applied mathematics, robust optimization, robust statistic, systems engineering, analytics, machine learning research, principal component analysis, computational optimization, multidimensional analysis

representative_papers.title: Adam: A Method for Stochastic Optimization
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Adam, a computationally efficient algorithm for optimizing stochastic objective functions using adaptive estimates of lower-order moments, highlighting its ease of implementation, low memory requirements, and effectiveness in handling large datasets and non-stationary objectives. It also discusses the theoretical convergence properties of Adam, its empirical performance compared to other methods, and presents AdaMax, a variant based on the infinity norm.

Topic: applied mathematics, stochastic optimization, mathematical optimization

representative_papers.title: FastTree: Computing Large Minimum Evolution Trees with Profiles instead of a Distance Matrix
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces FastTree, a novel method for constructing large minimum evolution trees using sequence profiles instead of traditional distance matrices, enabling efficient phylogenetic analysis of gene families with over 10,000 sequences. FastTree significantly reduces computational time and memory requirements while providing reliable tree estimates and improved accuracy compared to existing methods.

Topic: computational complexity, computer science, phylogenetic method, graph theory, combinatorics, combinatorial evolution, combinatorial theory, evolutionary biology, clustering, applied mathematics, vector space model, evolutionary computation, distance matrix, phylogenetics, feature construction, combinatorial optimization, automatic classification, machine vision

representative_papers.title: The Split Bregman Method for L1-Regularized Problems
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the Split Bregman Method, a novel approach to solving L1-regularized optimization problems, particularly in the context of compressed sensing and image denoising. It highlights the method's versatility in addressing various constrained problems and its application to the Rudin–Osher–Fatemi functional in magnetic resonance imaging.

Topic: approximation theory, parameter identification, variational analysis, numerical method for partial differential equation, mathematical optimization, mathematical programming, applied mathematics, split bregman method, numerical analysis, regularization (mathematics)
keywords: numerical method for partial differential equation

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 2017-2021, applied mathematics was characterized by advancements in numerical optimization algorithms for scientific computing. Papers such as 'Numerical Heat Transfer and Fluid Flow' (2018) demonstrate the application of computational methods to analyze heat transfer phenomena, while 'Introduction to Algorithms' (2018) provides a foundational understanding of algorithm design principles used across domains including fluid dynamics simulations. Additionally, tools like UMAP illustrate how efficient optimization techniques enhance dimensionality reduction for complex systems analysis.

representative_papers.title: Numerical Heat Transfer and Fluid Flow
representative_papers.abstract:
The book "Numerical Heat Transfer and Fluid Flow" explores the principles of heat and mass transfer, fluid dynamics, and related processes in various contexts, using accessible mathematical methods to develop numerical techniques for predicting these phenomena. It aims to enhance readers' understanding of transport phenomena and improve their analytical skills in interpreting computational results in engineering and applied sciences.

Topic: mechanical engineering, heat transfer, thermal engineering, fluid flow, numerical method for partial differential equation, transport phenomena, applied mathematics, numerical analysis, thermal modeling, applied physics, numerical heat transfer, fluid dynamics, numerical simulation, fluid mechanics
keywords: numerical method for partial differential equation

representative_papers.title: Numerical optimization
representative_papers.abstract:
The third edition of Braun and Murdoch's textbook on numerical optimization introduces design principles using tidyverse packages in R, with enhanced coverage of ggplot2 and R Markdown, along with new examples and exercises. It serves as a comprehensive guide for beginners in data science, emphasizing practical programming skills and providing resources such as downloadable code and solutions for real-world applications.

Topic: continuous optimization, engineering, engineering optimization, computational engineering, numerical computation, system optimization, global optimization, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, numerical algorithm, optimization problem, systems engineering, numerical analysis, dynamic optimization, design optimization, numerical optimization, computational optimization, computational science

representative_papers.title: A Mathematical Theory of Evidence
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a new theory of epistemic probability that builds on A. P. Dempster's work while diverging from his views, particularly in the context of combining inconclusive evidence in science and practical applications. It critiques traditional Bayesian approaches and develops an alternative additive set function theory, addressing limitations in statistical inference and providing elementary mathematical proofs in the appendices.

Topic: proof theory, information theory, information forensics, mathematical theory, statistical inference, mathematics, mathematical statistic, mathematical logic, automated deduction, evidential reasoning, bayesian analysis, probability theory, approximate reasoning, automated reasoning, automated proof, inference, biostatistics, statistical theory, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: Introduction to algorithms
representative_papers.abstract:
This textbook offers a practical introduction to convex optimization techniques, prioritizing understanding and application over technical details. It equips students and practitioners with the skills to recognize, model, and solve optimization problems across various fields, supported by clear explanations of linear algebra and numerous exercises.

Topic: computer science, algorithmic library, algorithmic mechanism design, algorithmic game theory, analysis of algorithm, computational optimization, algorithmic information theory, discrete algorithm, mathematical optimization, theoretical computer science, mathematical programming, numerical algorithm, computational science, theory of computation, computational mathematics, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: UMAP: Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection
representative_papers.abstract:
UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a fast and efficient dimension reduction technique that facilitates visualization and non-linear data reduction, offering a scikit-learn compatible API and support for supervised and semi-supervised learning. With a strong mathematical foundation, UMAP outperforms many t-SNE implementations and allows for the transformation of new data into a pretrained embedding space.

Topic: applied mathematics, differential geometry, manifold modeling, computational geometry, manifold learning, pade approximant, projection system, sparse representation, uniform manifold approximation, numerical simulation, approximation theory, computer science, geometric modeling, machine learning research

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1938-1948, applied mathematics saw significant advancements in communication theory through Claude Shannon's foundational work on information transmission. Earlier developments like the estimation of fifty percent endpoints (1938) and elasticity theories provided mathematical tools for analyzing complex systems, leading to a focus on quantitative methods for solving practical problems.

representative_papers.title: A Mathematical Theory of Communication
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the advancements in communication theory, particularly focusing on modulation methods like PCM and PPM that optimize bandwidth and signal-to-noise ratio. It aims to extend existing theories by incorporating new factors such as noise effects and the statistical structure of messages, drawing on foundational works by Nyquist and Hartley.

Topic: graph theory, applied mathematics, spectral theory, information theory, communication theory, mathematical control theory, mathematical optimization, mass communication, wavelet theory, mathematical theory, theoretical mathematics, scientific communication, communication complexity, mathematics, theory of computation, communication, speech communication, mathematical programming

representative_papers.title: A SIMPLE METHOD OF ESTIMATING FIFTY PER CENT ENDPOINTS12
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a straightforward method for estimating fifty percent endpoints, utilizing geometric interpolation and curve fitting techniques, which can be applied in various fields such as epidemiology, economics, and machine learning research for performance evaluation and comparative analysis.

Topic: economics, quantitative science study, partial evaluation, curve fitting, applied mathematics, simple method, geometric interpolation, benchmark study, statistics, machine learning research, performance evaluation, comparative analysis, numerical simulation

representative_papers.title: Theory of elasticity
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of the theory of elasticity, covering fundamental concepts such as stresses and strains, plasticity, and elasto-plastic behavior in materials. It explores various mechanical phenomena and applications in structural mechanics, emphasizing nonlinear elasticity and the mathematical principles underlying mechanical deformation.

Topic: mechanical behavior, mechanical engineering, metal, nonlinear elasticity, friction, nonlinear analysis, deformation, structural mechanics, elasticity (physics), rational mechanic, mechanical property, nonlinear phenomenon, applied mathematics, mechanical deformation, elasticity (economics), solid mechanics, mechanics of materials, physics

representative_papers.title: A Method of Computing the Effectiveness of an Insecticide
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a method for calculating the effectiveness of insecticides, focusing on the application of mathematical and statistical techniques in pest management and entomology. It aims to enhance the understanding of insecticide performance through a systematic approach to data analysis.

Topic: insecticide, pesticide science, applied mathematics, pest management, insect science, biostatistics, entomology

representative_papers.title: The Mathematical Theory of Communication
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the enduring significance of "The Mathematical Theory of Communication," a groundbreaking work in communication theory published over fifty years ago, which has influenced various fields such as information theory, mathematics, and communication. It highlights the book's remarkable foresight and its continued relevance, as evidenced by multiple printings and a recent commemorative reissue by the University of Illinois Press.

Topic: information theory, theory of computation, spectral theory, wavelet theory, mathematics, general system, graph theory, communication, mathematical theory, mathematical optimization, mathematical logic, communication theory, theoretical mathematics, applied mathematics, mathematical programming, communication complexity, mathematical control theory, speech communication, mass communication

final_period_characterizations.topic_label: Stochastic Processes and Graph Theory in Applied Mathematics
final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period of 1949-1958, applied mathematics experienced significant advancements through the development and application of stochastic processes to model complex phenomena like diffusion (The mathematics of diffusion, 1956) and irreversible processes. Concurrently, graph theory emerged as a crucial tool for solving combinatorial optimization problems, with papers such as On the shortest spanning subtree... providing foundational algorithms. These two paradigms developed somewhat independently but both reflected a broader shift towards probabilistic and discrete methods in tackling practical challenges.

representative_papers.title: On the shortest spanning subtree of a graph and the traveling salesman problem
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the relationship between the shortest spanning subtree of a graph and the traveling salesman problem, highlighting key concepts in graph theory, combinatorial optimization, and algebraic graph theory. It references significant works and problems in the field, emphasizing their implications for graph algorithms and mathematical structures.

Topic: graph theory, applied mathematics, algebraic graph theory, combinatorial optimization, graph algorithm

representative_papers.title: The mathematics of diffusion
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the mathematics of diffusion, focusing on the collection of solutions to diffusion equations and the methods for obtaining them, while also addressing various related topics such as nonlinear phenomena, boundary value problems, and numerical simulations in the context of diffusion processes.

Topic: applied mathematics, nonlinear phenomenon, boundary value problem, partial differential equation, differential equation, nonlinear dynamic, diffusion, anomalous diffusion, diffusion process, numerical simulation, information diffusion, stochastic diffusion search, mathematics, numerical mathematics, diffusion of innovation, stochastic process, transport phenomena

representative_papers.title: Boundary layer theory
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses boundary layer theory, focusing on the differences in flow behavior at high Reynolds numbers compared to laminar flow, particularly highlighting the characteristics of turbulence in pipe flow. It emphasizes the need for nonlinear analysis and advanced mathematical methods to understand the complexities of fluid motion near surfaces in various scientific and engineering applications.

Topic: nonlinear analysis, boundary element method, boundary value problem, civil engineering, materials science, boundary layer, applied mathematics, interface (matter), interface science, layered material, tectonics, partial differential equation, shell theory, boundary layer theory, surface science, solid mechanics

representative_papers.title: Methods of Theoretical Physics
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses various methods and approaches in theoretical physics, focusing on high-energy physics, applied mathematics, and computational techniques. It explores the intersection of theoretical modeling and mathematical physics, highlighting their significance in addressing theoretical issues within the field.

Topic: theoretical high-energy physic, applied mathematics, particle method, computational physic, mathematical physics, theoretical issue, theoretical mathematics, physics, theoretical modeling, theoretical physic, applied physics

representative_papers.title: Statistical-Mechanical Theory of Irreversible Processes. I. General Theory and Simple Applications to Magnetic and Conduction Problems
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a comprehensive exploration of a general fluctuation-dissipation theorem within the framework of statistical-mechanical theory, detailing how physical quantities like magnetic susceptibility and conductivity can be derived from time-fluctuation dynamics related to irreversible processes. It includes a rigorous examination of the formalism, response and correlation functions, and illustrates these concepts through simple applications in magnetic and conduction problems.

Topic: magnetism, thermal engineering, path dependence, irreversible processes, stochastic calculus, mechanical engineering, statistical-mechanical theory, simple applications, statistical theory, stochastic process, statistical inference, statistics, statistical mechanic, mathematical statistic, theoretical analysis, applied mathematics, magnetic resonance, conduction problems, statistical signal processing, nonlinear dynamic, statistical model, general theory, reliability engineering

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1959-1964, applied mathematics witnessed a surge in the study of nonlinear phenomena through rigorous mathematical analysis (An Analysis of Transformations, 1964) as well as innovative numerical methods for function minimization (Function minimization by conjugate gradients, 1964; An efficient method for finding the minimum...). The domain also saw advancements in computational approaches to complex systems like electrochemistry and polarography (Theory of Stationary Electrode Polarography..., 1964), reflecting a growing integration between mathematical theory and algorithmic computation. These developments built upon earlier stochastic modeling paradigms while establishing new foundations for tackling problems that required handling nonlinearity, which was central in many scientific applications from physics to engineering.

representative_papers.title: An Analysis of Transformations
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a less restrictive approach to data analysis by allowing for transformations of observations to achieve normality and homoscedasticity, rather than assuming these conditions from the outset. It explores the implications of these transformations on likelihood functions and posterior distributions, while also comparing current methods to earlier procedures for finding suitable transformations, supported by illustrative examples.

Topic: organizational transformation, cultural change, transformation kinetics, nonlinear analysis, nonlinear phenomenon, applied mathematics, energy transformation, chemical transformation, social transformation, integral transform

representative_papers.title: Principles of mathematical analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of the principles of mathematical analysis, covering topics such as number systems, topology, sequences, continuity, differentiation, integration, and advanced concepts like Lebesgue theory and differential forms, while also touching on various branches of mathematics including complex analysis and functional analysis. It serves as a foundational resource for understanding both theoretical and applied aspects of mathematical analysis.

Topic: mathematics, analytic number theory, nonlinear analysis, numerical mathematics, matrix analysis, abstract and applied analysis, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, complex analysis, foundation of mathematics, spectral theory, numerical analysis, mathematical science, functional analysis, abstract analysis, global analysis, mathematical analysis

representative_papers.title: Theory of Stationary Electrode Polarography. Single Scan and Cyclic Methods Applied to Reversible, Irreversible, and Kinetic Systems.
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the theory and application of stationary electrode polarography, focusing on single scan and cyclic methods for analyzing reversible, irreversible, and kinetic systems in electroanalytical chemistry. It provides insights into the underlying principles and methodologies relevant to electrical engineering and biophysics.

Topic: relaxation process, cyclic methods, electrical engineering, polarization imaging, kinetic systems, applied mathematics, stationary electrode polarography, electroanalytical chemistry, biophysics, electrochemistry

representative_papers.title: Function minimization by conjugate gradients
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a quadratically convergent gradient method for finding unconstrained local minima of multivariable functions, highlighting its simplicity and low storage requirements, as it only needs three vectors. It includes an ALGOL procedure and discusses results from various test functions to demonstrate the method's effectiveness in mathematical optimization.

Topic: computer science, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, function minimization, conjugate gradients, functional analysis

representative_papers.title: An efficient method for finding the minimum of a function of several variables without calculating derivatives
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents an efficient derivative-free method for minimizing functions of several variables by adjusting one parameter at a time, which enhances convergence rates and ensures effective approximations of the minimum. Practical applications and numerical examples demonstrate the method's effectiveness in optimizing functions with up to twenty variables.

Topic: several variables, computer science, approximation theory, variational analysis, global optimization, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, mathematical programming, derivative-free optimization, optimization problem, systems engineering, numerical analysis, multivariate approximation, efficient method, combinatorial optimization, conic optimization, design optimization, computational optimization

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1965-1978, applied mathematics was characterized by an intensive focus on numerical methods for analyzing complex nonlinear systems. This period saw the development of robust algorithms for optimization (e.g., 'A Simplex Method for Function Minimization') and computational approaches to fluid dynamics ('Numerical Calculation of Time-Dependent Viscous Incompressible Flow of Fluid with Free Surface'). The research emphasized stability, accuracy, and efficient computation in handling differential equations that govern phenomena from quantum mechanics to fluid behavior. This built upon earlier advancements in stochastic modeling and numerical optimization while addressing the increasing demand for computational solutions to intricate scientific problems.

representative_papers.title: Self-Consistent Equations Including Exchange and Correlation Effects
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of approximation methods for treating inhomogeneous systems of interacting electrons, building on the Hohenberg and Kohn theory. It presents self-consistent equations that incorporate exchange and correlation effects, analogous to Hartree and Hartree-Fock equations, and addresses the behavior of electronic systems at finite temperatures and in magnetic fields, along with corrections for short-wavelength density oscillations.

Topic: stability, differential equation, quantum science, dynamic equilibrium, correlation effects, diffusion, dynamical system, nonlinear phenomenon, applied mathematics, correlation, coexistence, coherent process, simultaneous equation modeling, applied physics, self-consistent equations, numerical simulation, ecology, bifurcation theory

representative_papers.title: A Simplex Method for Function Minimization
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a simplex method for minimizing functions of multiple variables by utilizing a general simplex structure that adapts to the local landscape, effectively replacing the vertex with the highest value to converge on the minimum. It highlights the computational efficiency of the approach and provides a procedure for estimating the Hessian matrix in the vicinity of the minimum, relevant for statistical applications.

Topic: computer science, function minimization, mathematical optimization, simplex method, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: A Theory of the Allocation of Time
representative_papers.abstract:
The article "A Theory of the Allocation of Time" by Gary S. Becker explores the economic principles governing how individuals allocate their time among various activities, integrating concepts from dynamic economics, mathematical optimization, and systems theory to analyze the complexities of time management as a resource.

Topic: economics, complex system, dynamic economics, temporal dynamic, theoretical economics, systems biology, dynamical system, applied mathematics, mathematical optimization, automatic control, ergodic theory, time series, temporal complexity, resource allocation, time delay system

representative_papers.title: Numerical Calculation of Time-Dependent Viscous Incompressible Flow of Fluid with Free Surface
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel numerical technique for analyzing time-dependent, viscous, incompressible fluid flow with a free surface, utilizing finite-difference methods to solve the Navier-Stokes equations. It incorporates a cell method with marker particles to track fluid movement, allowing for comprehensive simulation of non-linear and transient flow behaviors.

Topic: free surface, incompressible flow, unsteady flow, fluid flow, flow physic, applied mathematics, numerical calculation, numerical analysis, fluid dynamics, numerical simulation, fluid mechanics, computational fluid dynamic

representative_papers.title: The Fourier Transform and Its Applications
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of the Fourier Transform, covering its foundational concepts, mathematical principles, and various applications across fields such as statistics, optics, and heat conduction. It includes discussions on convolution, discrete Fourier transforms, and related theories, making it a valuable resource for understanding the significance and utility of Fourier analysis in applied mathematics and engineering.

Topic: applied mathematics, operator theory, spectral theory, fourier transform, harmonic analysis, fourier expansion, fourier analysis

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1979-1986, applied mathematics was dominated by advancements in statistics. This period saw the development of robust methods for handling heteroskedasticity (A Heteroskedasticity-Consistent Covariance Matrix Estimator...) and high-dimensional data through multivariate analysis (An Introduction to Multivariate Statistical Analysis). The integration of statistical theory with computational techniques, such

representative_papers.title: An Introduction to Multivariate Statistical Analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
This article serves as a comprehensive introduction to multivariate statistical analysis, covering key topics such as the multivariate normal distribution, estimation of mean vectors and covariance matrices, classification of observations, and various statistical tests and methodologies, including principal components and factor analysis. It is designed for readers interested in applied statistics and statistical theory, particularly in the context of high-dimensional data and biostatistics.

Topic: applied statistics, applied mathematics, statistical theory, multivariate analysis, biostatistics, high-dimensional statistics, statistics, statistical methodology

representative_papers.title: Norm-Conserving Pseudopotentials
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a straightforward method for deriving norm-conserving pseudopotentials from ab initio atomic calculations, ensuring that the resulting eigenvalues and nodeless eigenfunctions align with wave functions beyond a specified radius, thus enhancing the pseudopotentials' transferability.

Topic: mathematics, norm-conserving pseudopotentials, linear algebra, quantum science, parameter identification, mathematical optimization, applied mathematics, norm (mathematics), spectral theory, condensed matter physics, functional analysis, regularization (mathematics)

representative_papers.title: Spectrum estimation and harmonic analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
This article presents a novel method for spectrum estimation of stationary time series using local eigenexpansion, addressing bias control and smoothing issues without arbitrary windows. The approach is computationally efficient, consistent, and offers high resolution, while also providing analysis-of-variance tests and connections to maximum-likelihood estimates and polyspectrum coherence.

Topic: spectrum estimation, applied mathematics, harmonic analysis

representative_papers.title: Official Methods of Analysis of
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the Official Methods of Analysis, focusing on the methodologies and statistical techniques used in various fields, including political science and economic analysis, to evaluate performance and conduct quantitative research. It highlights the importance of formal methods and statistical methodologies in ensuring accurate and reliable results in applied statistics.

Topic: methodology comparison, political science research, evaluation technique, methodological article, statistical theory, economic analysis, applied statistics, performance studies, methodological development, statistics, performance evaluation, quantitative science study, mathematical analysis, official methods, formal methods, statistical methodology, statistical analysis, applied mathematics, software analysis

representative_papers.title: A Heteroskedasticity-Consistent Covariance Matrix Estimator and a Direct Test for Heteroskedasticity
representative_papers.abstract:
This article introduces a heteroskedasticity-consistent covariance matrix estimator for linear regression models that remains valid regardless of the specific structure of heteroskedasticity. It also provides a direct test for heteroskedasticity by comparing this new estimator with traditional ones, highlighting their divergence in the presence of heteroskedastic disturbances.

Topic: high-dimensional statistics, econometric method, applied mathematics, direct test, statistics

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period of 1987-1994, applied mathematics was characterized by significant advancements in statistical inference methods. The publication of 'An Introduction to the Bootstrap' (1994) exemplifies this trend with its focus on resampling techniques for robust estimation and confidence intervals. Concurrently, papers such as 'Applied Logistic Regression' (1990) demonstrate a growing interest in applied statistics for analyzing categorical data and health-related phenomena. The period also saw continued developments in numerical analysis, particularly through the study of nonlinear systems using quaternions ('Closed-form solution of absolute orientation using unit quaternions', 1987). These two themes coexisted and evolved somewhat independently but reflected a broader integration of mathematical theory with practical data analysis problems.

representative_papers.title: Real and Complex Analysis.
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of real and complex analysis, covering key topics such as abstract integration, Lp-spaces, Hilbert space theory, and holomorphic functions, along with their applications in various mathematical contexts. It includes detailed discussions on measures, differentiation, transforms, and properties of analytic functions, making it a valuable resource for both theoretical and applied mathematics.

Topic: nonlinear analysis, abstract and applied analysis, applied mathematics, complex analysis, real analysis, real algebraic geometry, mathematical analysis

representative_papers.title: Closed-form solution of absolute orientation using unit quaternions
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a closed-form solution for determining the absolute orientation between two coordinate systems using unit quaternions, addressing a classic problem in photogrammetry and robotics. It simplifies the least-squares approach for aligning three or more points by emphasizing the symmetry properties of the rotation and providing exact results that outperform traditional empirical and iterative methods.

Topic: geometry and topology, computer science, geometric modeling, spectral theory, planetary sciences, geometry processing, algebraic geometry, unit quaternions, structure from motion, geometric quantization, absolute orientation, clifford algebra, computational geometry, differential geometry, function space, machine vision, geometric topology, closed-form solution, integral geometry, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: An Introduction to the Bootstrap
representative_papers.abstract:
This article introduces bootstrap methods for statistical estimation, providing straightforward explanations and Minitab macros for implementation. It covers key concepts in statistical inference and machine learning, emphasizing the practical applications of bootstrap resampling in data science.

Topic: computer science, forecasting, bootstrap resampling, statistical foundation, theory of computation, statistical inference, machine learning, applied mathematics, numerical algorithm, empirical algorithmics, foundation of mathematics, data science, knowledge discovery, statistical theory, machine learning research, quantitative science study, foundation model

representative_papers.title: Applied logistic regression
representative_papers.abstract:
The article reviews the revised edition of "Applied Logistic Regression" by David Stanley, highlighting its accessible approach to logistic regression models, minimal use of mathematics, and incorporation of recent advancements in biostatistics and machine learning. It emphasizes the book's practical examples and comprehensive guidance for readers across various fields, making it a valuable resource for statisticians and data scientists.

Topic: applied statistics, applied mathematics, applied economics, statistics, statistical inference, applied logic, model selection, logistic regression, classification method, data science, applied probability

representative_papers.title: Structural equation modeling in practice: A review and recommended two-step approach.
representative_papers.abstract:
This article offers a practical guide for researchers on implementing structural equation modeling (SEM) in theory testing and development, presenting a recommended two-step approach that utilizes nested models and chi-square difference tests. It highlights the advantages of this method over a one-step approach and reviews key considerations in model specification, fit assessment, and measurement respecification through confirmatory factor analysis.

Topic: applied mathematics, modeling and simulation, structural equation modeling, mathematical model

final_period_characterizations.topic_label: Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
